Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Female Counterstrategies to Male Aggression Among Primates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study focuses on the interacting male and female reproductive strategies of hamadryas baboons, a nonhuman primate with a unique and complex multilevel social system in which males transfer females between social units. The hamadryas social system may have more parallels to humans of any nonhuman primate, thus this study has great potential to enhance our understanding of human social evolution. In addition, this study will provide empirical data from wild animals to improve captive animal management in zoological parks in the USA and may also inform human obstetrics and gynecology. The project will support researcher training, conservation awareness, prevention of human-wildlife conflict, and improvement of snake-bite treatment options in areas surrounding the research site.

Hamadryas takeovers involve substantial male aggression; they lead to delayed reproduction in females as well as higher rates of infanticide and infant mortality in general. Using observational behavioral data and endocrine measures from fecal hormone samples collected from wild hamadryas baboon females at Filoha, Ethiopia, the investigators will study female strategies that may function to counteract this coercion and its implications. For example, lactating females may display false signals of sexual receptivity to males post-takeover, thereby preventing the loss of a dependent infant. In addition, pregnant females may use a strategy of pregnancy termination post-takeover, thus mitigating the eventual loss of investment in offspring. This project would be the first to provide hormonal evidence of deceptive swellings in any primate species, as well as the first to provide hormonal evidence for pregnancy failure in hamadryas baboons. More broadly, the results of this study will fill gaps in the theoretical scientific literature on sexual selection, sexual conflict, and the co-evolution of male and female reproductive strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study focused on the physiological impact of aggressive takeovers among wild hamadryas baboons in Ethiopia.  Hamadryas are unique among primates in their male-dominated, multi-level social system in which males aggressively coerce females into one-male units, a.k.a. harems, in order to secure them as mates and ensure paternity.  Every few years these females are taken over by a new male, who uses aggression to defeat the previous male and coerce the female into his unit.  Thus females incur multiple takeovers throughout their lives and the more takeovers males engage in, the more offspring they will sire. 

 

In this study we sought to uncover the physiological, mainly hormonal, impact of these aggressive takeovers on both males and females.  We collected fecal samples from individuals before and after takeovers and quantified glucocorticoid, or stress hormone, levels in those individuals at various points in time.  We then compared each individual's baseline stress hormone levels to those just after a takeover.  We also compared stress hormone levels between females across reproductive states and between males that had females and those that did not.  Analyses are still ongoing, with final results expected later this year.  So far our results suggest that stress hormone levels rise after takeovers for all individuals involved, that pregnant females have higher stress hormone levels than lactating or cycling females, and that bachelor males have higher stress hormone levels than leader males.  In addition, an analysis of observational data suggests that one of the outcomes of takeovers for females is pregnancy failure, or miscarriage, known as the Bruce Effect.

 

The results of this study have implications for our understanding of sexual coercion and the physiological impact of aggressive behavior.  The aggressive and coercive nature of the hamadryas pair bond has strong parallels with coercive controlling pair bonds in humans, and thus a better understanding of the hormonal basis of sexual coercion in hamadryas baboons may help us better understand the physiology of domestic violence in humans and lead to the development of better treatment or prevention, thereby contributing to human health and medicine.  On a broader level, the multilevel society of hamadryas baboons is arguably one of the best nonhuman primate models for the evolution of human social organization, thus a better understanding of this system in hamadryas can help us understand the evolution of our own society. 

 

In addition to its intellectual significance, this study contributed to the scientific training of a female scholar, Alexis Amann, who intends to use this training to contribute to zoo-based education and outreach in an urban center while continuing comparative research on wild primates.  This study has also provided field research training and experience for six female college graduates and thereby helped prepare them for graduate studies.  Finally, this project has contributed to a long term data set on hamadryas baboon behavior at the only field site with a habituated, individually identifiable population of this species and has enhanced the physical infrastructure and conservation status of Awash National Park and its wildlife.
